image.altText: Big sign saying Australian National University.

props.synopsis: The Australian National University says it is "deeply sorry" for the error that saw 2,290 former and current casual staff miss payments totalling about $2 million during the past 11 years, and had self-reported to the Fair Work Ombudsman.

title.children: More than 2,000 casual Australian National University staff underpaid over 11 years due to timesheet error

image.altText: Bruce Lehrman leaves the Federal Court of Australia in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer tells the Federal Court the former Liberal staffer wants to delay paying the $2 million he owes to Network Ten, pending a possible appeal against the ruling in his failed defamation case.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann seeking to delay paying $2 million he owes to Network Ten, Federal Court told

image.altText: Former rugby player Kirby Sefo stands smiling holding a rugby ball at a sporting field.

props.synopsis: The Australian Women's Rugby Union team has enjoyed increased investment and employed their first full-time coach this year, but the Wallaroos' most recent result shows they're still off the pace from the world's best.

title.children: Kirby took out a personal loan to finance her rugby dreams — it took her years to pay off

image.altText: A prohibition notice is stuck to the closed doors of Central Cafe in Gungahlin.

props.synopsis: The then 15-year-old had been working at a Canberra cafe when she was hospitalised with a salmonella infection.

title.children: Teenage kitchen hand awarded $65,000 after contracting salmonella at work

image.altText: a towering building is covered in futuristic red panels and laced with large silver exterior pipes

props.synopsis: The "cloud" that powers everything from sending an email to asking an AI chatbot a question needs massive amounts of power to run, and that's making energy experts nervous.

title.children: Power-hungry data centres scrambling to find enough electricity to meet demand

image.altText: Strobe lights surround an illuminated Eiffel Tower at night

props.synopsis: The opening ceremony for the 2024 Olympic Games, held almost entirely along Paris's River Seine, promises to be the most spectacular ever attempted — but it brings with it many complications and immeasurable risk.

title.children: Inside the Paris opening ceremony — the most spectacular and riskiest ever attempted

image.altText: Marina Hegering of Germany scores against Australia in thefirst group game of the Paris Olympic Games on July 26, 2024

props.synopsis: The Matildas' Olympic campaign is off to a rocky start, losing to Germany 3-0 in their opening game in Marseille.

title.children: Matildas fall 3-0 to Germany in Olympic opener

image.altText: A group of protesters standing in front of a white government building holding placards

props.synopsis: The Hostages and Missing Families Forum, representing the families of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas on October 7, says the government's "foot-dragging" is undermining their chance of survival.

title.children: Israeli hostage-release deal 'deliberately sabotaged' by Netanyahu government, advocacy group says

image.altText: Older woman with grey hair holding a colourful hand knitted doll.

props.synopsis: Carolyn Crawford's addiction to the pokies was so bad she used to hear their bells while lying in bed at night. She says the only way to save chronic gamblers from jail is through a system of "gambling courts".

title.children: She'd never even had a parking fine, but Carolyn's pokies addiction landed her in jail at 64

image.altText: Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: Ahead of the June quarter inflation figure out on Wednesday, the collective holding of breath is palpable. That number, and its consequences, could affect the government's political fortunes for months.

title.children: Behind the scenes, something is preoccupying the government — and it's not the cabinet reshuffle

image.altText: A North Korean flag sits behind lines of lime green code on a black background

props.synopsis: The United States, South Korea and United Kingdom say the campaign shows how dangerous North Korea is as it tries to support its nuclear ambitions.

title.children: NASA and US military bases hit by North Korean cyber criminals, US and allies say

image.altText: Rohan Taylor speaks at a media conference ahead of the Paris Olympics.

props.synopsis: Swimming Australia head coach Rohan Taylor says coach Michael Palfrey will face "consequences" for his inflammatory comments when the Paris Games finish.

title.children: 'Un-Australian' swimming coach to face consequences over Korea comments, but only after Paris Olympics

image.altText: Waves rise high after striking a seawall next to a road, as cars pass

props.synopsis: Efforts are underway to clean up an oil spill that could reach the Philippines capital following the sinking of a tanker in rough seas.

title.children: Typhoon Gaemi hits China after sinking ships and causing an oil spill that threatens Philippines capital

image.altText: a woman with a blunt grey bob

props.synopsis: Young adults are increasingly drawing on the "bank of mum and dad" no matter what their parents' income and for far more than a housing deposit, researchers have found.

title.children: How far would you go to help an adult child get a home? This woman moved into a flat in her backyard

image.altText: Monkeypox view under the microscope

props.synopsis: Australia is experiencing a resurgence of mpox, prompting alerts from state health departments as clusters of the virus continue to grow.

title.children: Calls to limit sexual partners as mpox makes a resurgence in Australia

image.altText: Women, children and men gather in a village under a palm tree in Papua New Guinea

props.synopsis: Violent attacks on three remote villages in Papua New Guinea's north has reportedly killed 26 people, including 16 children, while several people were forced to flee after attackers set fire to their homes, the United Nations said.

title.children: People beheaded, a village burned amid brutal violence in PNG province

image.altText: Spray bottle of Roundup on hardware store shelf

props.synopsis: There is insufficient evidence to prove the controversial weedkiller Roundup causes cancer, the Federal Court has ruled.

title.children: Landmark class action against weedkiller Roundup thrown out

image.altText: An illustration of a very tall man with an 18th century tricorne hat on. Other people come up to his elbows in height

props.synopsis: Known as the Irish Giant, Charles Byrne's dying wish was to be buried at sea to avoid being dissected and displayed after he died. But he was betrayed and centuries later the debate over where his remains should rest continues.

title.children: The 'Irish Giant' was petrified of becoming a surgeon's plaything. A betrayal saw his worst fears come true

image.altText: The artist wears a grey jumper covered in paint, and has save brown and grey hair. He stands smiling in AGNSW next to paintings

props.synopsis: After decades of being locked out of the art world, Thom Roberts feels "happy and beautiful" seeing his work displayed in the Archibald and Sulman prizes.

title.children: 'Just because you have a disability doesn't mean the only art you can do is therapy': Thom Roberts is a four-time Archibald finalist

image.altText: A shot from behind of a mother and a son sitting on a park bench.

props.synopsis: The Closing the Gap strategy set out to halve the rate of First Nations children in out-of-home care by 2031, but the numbers are still climbing.

title.children: Tahnee has two years to turn things around or her children could be removed

image.altText: Linda Burney smiles and waves as she leaves a press conference. She is next to the Aboriginal and Australian flags.

props.synopsis: The Indigenous Australians minister says she gave everything she could "with all her heart" to advance reconciliation and improve the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

title.children: 'I won't be the last': Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney bows out after a trailblazing career

image.altText: Nine newspapers

props.synopsis: Journalists from multiple major Australian newspapers have announced they will go on strike from Friday morning, on the eve of the Paris Olympics.

title.children: Journalists from The Age, SMH and other Nine Publishing mastheads announce strike on eve of Olympics

image.altText: Devil's Thumb on Federation Peak

props.synopsis: The co-conqueror of Mount Everest, Sir Edmund Hillary, described it as Australia's "only true mountain". But, with a death just this week bringing home the dangers, climbers know Tasmania's Federation Peak is not for the faint of heart.

title.children: The deadly lure of 'Australia's only true mountain', Federation Peak

image.altText: Generic hospital equipment in a patient's room.

props.synopsis: Australian health services and veterinary clinics are conserving their stock of intravenous fluid or using alternative products amid a global shortage of saline solutions.

title.children: Global shortage of saline solution puts Australian health authorities on alert

image.altText: ASA boss, Vice Admiral Jonathan Mead

props.synopsis: The head of the Australian Submarine Agency warns of a "long road ahead" with the trilateral security pact for nuclear submarines between Australia, the US and the UK.

title.children: Submarine boss predicts AUKUS will be slow, expensive and suffer setbacks

image.altText: Joe Biden sits at a desk in the Oval Office, wearing blue tie, pointing with one hand

props.synopsis: In an Oval Office address to explain why he abandoned his re-election bid, Joe Biden said he believes he's earned a second term as US president, but "personal ambition" cannot get in the way of saving democracy.

title.children: 'Kings and dictators do not rule': Biden's Oval Office address on why he quit the race for re-election

image.altText: A person's hand putting a coin, that looks like a clock, into a piggy bank

props.synopsis: An emergency fund is crucial for surviving the crises of life. But almost 20 per cent of Australians wouldn't be able to cover an unexpected expense worth $3,000.

title.children: An emergency fund protects you from life's unexpected events. Here's how much you should have saved

image.altText: A man in a suit smiling and waving

props.synopsis: The Israeli PM made a forceful, combative and unapologetic speech in the US centre of political power, and while one side of his audience was in raptures, the other seemed less convinced.

title.children: Netanyahu has counted on America for decades, but his address showed support could be fraying

image.altText: A police scene cordoned off.

props.synopsis: Two men die at a cattle station in Camballin in WA's Kimberley region, after the helicopters they were piloting collided, police confirm.

title.children: Helicopters collide and crash shortly after take-off on WA cattle station, killing both pilots

image.altText: Fire burns a tree in the foreground, while the background forest is reduced to silhouette by smoke.

props.synopsis: Wildfire has begun burning buildings in the town of Jasper, threatening a major oil pipeline.

title.children: Canada fires threaten oil pipeline at idyllic tourist town

image.altText: A group of rugby league players celebrate a try

props.synopsis: The Knights have escaped with a narrow victory to open the NRLW season after the Roosters missed a simple late conversion which would have sent the match to golden point.

title.children: Shock conversion miss delivers Knights epic win in NRLW season opener

image.altText: The Eiffel Tower lit up at night

props.synopsis: The next fortnight will be packed with sport and pageantry. Here's how to keep up with all the latest updates.

title.children: How to stay across the Olympics on the ABC

image.altText: Alice Milliat sits and looks to one side

props.synopsis: At the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, men and women are represented equally for the first time, thanks in part to a French pioneer who helped force the IOC and World Athletics to recognise female athletes.

title.children: This woman was treated as an irritation for most of her life. It's thanks to her the Paris Olympics have an equal gender split today

image.altText: A composite photo of Kaylee McKeown Shayna Jack and Mollie O'Callaghan

props.synopsis: Australia's swimming team has been a veritable medal factory in recent Olympic Games and the expectation in Paris is no different. Here are the Aussie swimmers to watch.

title.children: From Titmus to McKeown — these are the Aussie swimmers carrying our golden hopes in Paris
